Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 5: The gestation

To watch over the Bodhisattva during the gestative period, Indra sent four young hero gods, Khadgapani (Lag na ral gri), Shulapani (Lag na mdung), Tomarapani (Lag na mda 'bo che) and Shaktipani (Lag na mdung thung).
Inscription - English: Four young gods holding weapons protect the bodhisattva while he resides in the womb
Manual - Tibetan (བོད་ཡིག།): ཡང་དེ་དག་དང་ཉེ་བའི་ཁང་བཟང་གཅིག་ཏུ། ཡུམ་གྱི་སྐུའི་ལྟོ་བ་ན། བྱང་ཆུབ་སེམས་དཔའ་ལྷུམས་སུ་ཞུགས་པ་ནི། ལྷའི་སྐུ་འདྲ་བ་འོད་ཟེར་འཕྲོ་བས་བརྒྱན་པ་དང་། ཡུམ་གྱི་སྐུ་གཡས་གཡོན་དུ་ལྷའི་བགྲུང་མ་བཞི། རལ་གྲི་དང་། མདུང་དང་། མདུང་ཐུང་དང་། མདའ་བོ་ཆེ་རྣམས་འཛིན་པ་ཡོད་པ།  འཁོར་གཡོག་མང་པོ་མཆོད་པ་སྣ་ཚོགས་པའི་རྣམ་པ་འབྲིའོ། །དེ་ནས་རྒྱལ་པོས་བཙོན་རྣམས་བཏང་བ་དང། ཀུན་ཏུ་རྒྱུ་མིག་དམར་ཞེས་བྱ་བ། ད་ལྟའི་སཱ་བྱ་ཤིའི་ཆ་ལུགས་འདྲ་བ་ཅིག་གིས། རྒྱ་མཚོ་བཞིའི་ཆུ་ཡུམ་ལ་འདྲེན་པའི་རྣམ་པ་རྣམས་འདྲིའོ། །རྒྱལ་པོ་ཟ་གཙང་མ་ཡང་དེ་གཉིས་ན་ཉེ་བ་ན་བཞུགས་པ་རེ་བྱ།
Manual - English: In a mansion near the king's palace, the Buddha, like a god emanating rays of light and wearing jewelry, enters the womb of the queen. The queen is surrounded by four protector gods holding a sword, spear, short spear, and large arrows, respectively. A large retinue make various offerings. The king sets free his prisoners. A yogi or wanderer known as Lohita (mig dmar), resembling a Sāchashi (sA bya shi) follower today, offers water from the four seas to the mother. King Śuddhodana (zas gtsang ma) dwells near them.

Sun of Faith - English: The time in his mother's womb did not defile the unborn child in any way:
visible through his mother's stomach, his splendid body shone like the gleaming heart of a lapis lazuli stone.
From the instant that the Bodhisattva went into her womb until the day she died, Mahamaya-devi kept the five precepts.
Not once was her mind troubled by desire.
During this uncommon gestation period, the queen sojourned in the various palace parks, surrounded by unimaginable beauties and comforts.
Any least pain or sadness was carefully spared her: her happiness equaled that of goddesses in paradise.
One day, an odd craving for drinking the waters of the four oceans came to her.
The queen confided it to her husband, who subsequently consulted the oracle priests.
“This wish comes to her from the child, not from her own self.
It means that your son will drink the ocean of all-knowing.”
And what will happen if the queen herself does not get to drink such waters?” the king asked.
“The child will be born with imperfect limbs.”
“I cannot allow my son to be born with an infirmity,” Shuddhodana remarked trenchantly.
He then had a yogi, an itinerant by name of Lohita (Mig dmar) who was expert at casting spells, brought to him.
By reciting mantras, Lohita managed to conjure up the waters of the four oceans.
Inscription - English: Offering waters of the four oceans

Sun of Faith - English: These were offered to the queen, whose craving was thus satisfied.
Furthermore, when Mahamaya-devi wished that the prison doors would open, Shuddhodana freed all the prisoners.
When she expressed a desire to feed the poor, the king supplied food and other provisions to the whole population.
And when the queen asked to visit every one of their parks and gardens, her husband complied immediately.
